question: [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Authorization Bypass] Can an attacker front-run the legitimate authority's transaction to change the aggregator authority via set_authority_action, then call run() with their own context to bypass the has_authority check and set malicious configs? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Authorization Bypass] If has_authority() only checks ctx.sender() against aggregator.authority, can an attacker exploit a shared object race condition where multiple transactions modify authority simultaneously, allowing unauthorized config updates? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: run()] [TOCTOU] Between validate() checking has_authority at line 42 and actuate() calling set_configs at line 58, can the aggregator's authority be changed by a concurrent transaction, allowing an unauthorized user to update configs after authority validation passed? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Authorization] If the authority address is set to @0x0 or a burn address during aggregator creation, does has_authority always return false, permanently bricking the aggregator's configuration update capability? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Privilege Escalation] Can an attacker create a malicious TxContext wrapper or proxy that spoofs ctx.sender() to match the aggregator authority, bypassing the has_authority check at line 42? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Version Check] If EXPECTED_AGGREGATOR_VERSION is hardcoded to 1 at line 6, what happens if the Aggregator module is upgraded to version 2 but this action module is not updated, causing all config update attempts to fail with EInvalidAggregatorVersion? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Upgrade Path] If an aggregator is created with version 2+ and this action still expects version 1, can users never update configs, creating a permanent DoS where aggregators with outdated staleness or sample size settings cannot be fixed? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Version Downgrade] Can an attacker exploit a vulnerability in the Aggregator module to manually set version back to 0 or MAX_U8, bypassing the version check at line 41 even though the aggregator should be version 1? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [DoS] Can an attacker with authority set min_sample_size to MAX_U64 (line 43 only checks > 0), making it impossible for the aggregator to ever produce valid results since valid_update_indices.length() can never reach MAX_U64? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Oracle Manipulation] Can an attacker set min_sample_size to 1 (passes line 43 check), allowing single-oracle manipulation where one compromised oracle can control the aggregator result without needing consensus from multiple oracles? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Griefing] If min_sample_size is set to a value larger than MAX_RESULTS (16 from aggregator.move), the aggregator can never meet the minimum sample requirement in compute_current_result, causing permanent result computation failure and vault price oracle DoS? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Business Logic] If min_sample_size is set to 17 or higher (> MAX_RESULTS), does line 344 in aggregator.move's compute_current_result always return option::none(), making the aggregator permanently unusable for Volo Vault price feeds? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Oracle Manipulation] Line 44 only checks max_variance > 0, so can an attacker set it to MAX_U64, allowing oracle results with extreme variance to be accepted, enabling price manipulation where oracles report values from 0.01 to 1000000 and still pass validation? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Oracle Manipulation] Can an attacker set max_variance to 1 (passes line 44), causing the aggregator to reject all legitimate oracle updates that have natural variance, forcing stale price data that can be exploited in vault operations? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Price Manipulation] If max_variance is set to an extremely high value like 10^18, does the aggregator accept oracle results where some oracles report $1 and others report $1B for the same asset, allowing manipulation of vault total_usd_value calculations? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Variance Check Bypass] Since set_configs at line 58 doesn't re-validate the actual current oracle variance, can an attacker first set max_variance=MAX_U64, wait for manipulated oracle updates to be accepted, then set max_variance back to a normal value to hide the attack? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Feed Hash Manipulation] Line 45 only checks feed_hash.length() == 32, so can an attacker set feed_hash to all zeros (0x0000...0000) which passes length validation but points to no actual feed, causing oracle updates to fail and DoS the price oracle? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Feed Switch Attack] Can an attacker with authority switch feed_hash from a legitimate SUI/USD feed to a different feed (e.g., ETH/USD) mid-operation, causing the Volo Vault to use wrong price data for asset valuation without any semantic validation? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Feed Continuity] When feed_hash is changed at line 58, are the existing oracle results in update_state cleared? If not, can old results from the previous feed pollute the new feed's computation, mixing SUI/USD and ETH/USD prices? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Hash Collision] Can an attacker find a 32-byte collision that passes line 45 validation but maps to a malicious or non-existent feed, allowing them to control oracle data sources? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: run()] [Feed Validation] Since there's no check that feed_hash corresponds to an active/registered feed in the queue system, can an attacker set an arbitrary 32-byte hash that no oracles will ever update, causing permanent staleness? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Oracle Collusion] Line 46 only checks min_responses > 0, so can an attacker set min_responses to 1, allowing a single compromised oracle to provide valid updates without requiring multiple oracle consensus? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [DoS] Can an attacker set min_responses to MAX_U32, making it impossible for any feed jobs to collect that many oracle responses, permanently disabling oracle updates and causing vault price staleness? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Inconsistency] If min_responses is set to 10 but min_sample_size is set to 3, which constraint takes precedence in compute_current_result? Can this mismatch cause inconsistent result validation where updates are accepted but results aren't computed? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Type Mismatch] min_responses is u32 while min_sample_size is u64 - can this type difference cause comparison issues where min_responses=MAX_U32 is less than min_sample_size=MAX_U64, creating conflicting validation logic? (Low)
